awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Platform for Commercial Dialogue Systems with Fluid Turn-Taking Skills
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is that it will make progress toward the societal need to increase the efficiency and flexibility with which people can talk to computers, and reduce the frustration that many people feel in trying to get things done with current speech-enabled systems. Commercial applications of speech-enabled systems are increasing very rapidly, including systems that act as virtual assistants, automate customer service functions, and generally enable people to get things done with their voices in their homes, cars, and throughout daily life. As these applications expand throughout society, we will inevitably find ourselves speaking to automated systems more and more often. The company's innovative platform is designed to enable people to communicate more naturally and efficiently in these interactions. This project will develop ways to improve how people can communicate as they interact with speech-based applications developed by a variety of businesses and organizations. The project will enhance understanding of how advanced research innovations in dialogue systems technology can be brought into the commercial arena and contribute to the technical development of an innovative new dialogue platform. 

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project advances the development and commercialization of language processing and dialogue system technologies that increase the efficiency and naturalness of speaking to an automated system while reducing user frustration. The project addresses technical hurdles in the standardization of software architecture, generalization of language processing models, and methods for authoring and controlling the content of automated conversations. The objective for Phase I is to demonstrate the overall technical feasibility of the proposed conversational platform. The project plan includes data collection, technical development, and evaluation steps to achieve this objective. An anticipated outcome is an improved understanding of the most promising technical avenues to enable more natural conversational skills in commercial dialogue systems.

por.por_cntn:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project has
pursued the societal need to increase the efficiency and flexibility
with which people can talk to computers, and to reduce the frustration
that many people feel in trying to get things done with current
speech-enabled systems.  Commercial applications of speech-enabled
systems are increasing very rapidly, including systems that act as
virtual assistants, automate customer service functions, and generally
enable people to get things done with their voices in their homes,
cars, and throughout daily life.  As these applications expand
throughout society, we will inevitably find ourselves speaking to
automated systems more and more often.

In this project, an innovative software platform has been developed
that is designed to enable people to communicate more naturally and
efficiently with computers.  The new software platform brings together
a number of research-based technologies for speech and language
processing.  These technologies relate to different aspects of how
computers can recognize and understand language as people use it in
natural conversations.  The project has also addressed technical
hurdles in the standardization of software architecture,
generalization of language processing models, and methods for
controlling the content of automated conversations.

Beyond software, the project has included an evaluation effort that
investigated people's preferences for different ways of providing
information to computer systems.  For a specific task, this evaluation
showed that there are many people who prefer a conversational style of
interaction over a more traditional user interface based on mouse and
keyboard input.

Overall, this project has advanced the development and
commercialization of language processing and dialogue system
technologies that may soon help to increase the efficiency and
naturalness of speaking to automated systems.
